content: Social consensus here means end-users or their delegates installing a client update that includes an irregular state change that slashes certain misbehaving validators.

content: These would be any validators who participated in an attack of the network, after the attack occurred.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: An irregular state change is when an Ethereum execution clients update does a one-time mutation of the state trie outside of the normal EVM/consensus ruleset.

author: fradamt
content: I think there's maybe one important difference between "normal" MEV extraction, which can be single-handedly done by a proposer, and this. The more validators decide extracting MEV isn't ethical, the more MEV they leave on the table and the faster the MEV extractors accrue power, both directly and through people wanting the higher yields and staking with them, so there's no way to mount opposition. Even a minority of extractors can grow very powerful fast. For this MEV from reorgs, it only works if you get enough validators on board that they can force the reorgs, or the game doesn't even start. You can't attract people with higher yields without having already gotten significant stake on board

author: potuz
content: In order to be able to pull a successful reorg on the beacon-chain, the proposer needs to hold a majority of attesters on that slot that are willing to not follow rules regarding LMD Ghost vote. To not have it reverted in the next slot they'll need that as well. Any system you choose, no matter what form of proof you use, will be vulnerable to these attacks if a large majority of the players that are in charge of producing blocks, be it pow, pos or whatever, act in bad faith. Decentralization**is** a way of making this more difficult, but it does rely on the good faith of the majority.
